body: Yes. This is something that is available in scattering.m for example and it's really useful
The other potential advantage here, from what I understand, is that it may give us a way to compute filters independent of image size, since we're storing them in the spatial/time domain.

issue.title: ENH Use real filterbank in Scattering2D

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body: The Morlet/Gabor filterbank in Scattering2D is actually real-valued when expressed in the spectral domain. We can exploit this in the computation. (Possibly needs a test to make sure all code paths in cdgmm are covered.)

body: Working with 1D data of shape `(384, 300000)` is showing me the limitations of not having this implemented. My GPU maxes out in memory at `(30, 300000)`, which, if we made this into one long line, would correspond to like 400s of mono audio at 22050. It might be nice to be able to go a bit above that without having to manually chunk data etc

As a bioacoustician, i routinely work on input waveforms that are a billion samples long or more. Overlap-add is essential in this case. And 👍 for working independently of image size. This opens the path for training fully convolutional models and recurrent models
Maybe one of you can explain the basic concept, and I can try to implement this one of these days?

issue.title: API Conv prim

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body: This PR adds the convolution primitive, which generalizes the scattering convolution operation. This PR  will eventually resolve issue #305. Perhaps we can resolve issue #445 ?

issue.title: T → N

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body: As part of our discussion on separating the wavelet scale from the averaging scale, we realized that the variable T is already being used in 1D for the size of the signals. In the 2D code (and in scatnet, I think), this is denoted N, so I suggest we rename T to N. This would then free up T as the averaging scale parameter.

body:
[copied from a Discord discussion]

N>>T is the typical use case of variable-length input. 

To address it, pick a buffer size M>T  (M is the maximal support of the wavelets/phi). M depends solely on the Scattering1D object, not on the input itself.

Then, given a signal x of length N>>M, divide x into C overlapping chunks of length M. I think that a default overlap of 50% is sensible.
Note that padding is only needed for the first and last chunk. For all the chunks in between, we can use overlap as a form of "natural padding".

In scattering.m i have experimented with two variants of this chunking procedure: "Hann" and "Tukey", after the name of the window functions applied to every chunk. In both variants, the number of scattering frames per chunk should be a multiple of 4. (so N=4T sounds about right?)

Here's the layout i imagine: 
```
chunk A: 0 1 2 3
chunk B:     0 1 2 3
chunk C:         0 1 2 3
chunk D:             0 1 2 3
```

(again, this example takes 4 frames per chunk but the idea can work with more frames too)

In the Hann variant, one would sum the responses on a per-chunk basis (no FFT needed!) and end up with the sequence [A, B, C, D] 
The appeal of this is that it potentially allows us to skip the phi  conv stage and replace it by this per-chunk sum which has linear complexity.
So i think that the Hann variant could be the best choice if (1)average=True  and (2) the averaging scaleT is greater or equal than the maximum wavelet scale
Now, in the Tukey variant, one would discard the 25% left portion and the 25% right portion of every chunk
```
chunk A:   1 2 
chunk B:       1 2 
chunk C:           1 2 
chunk D:               1 2 
```
 
and then stitch the segments together:
[A1, A2, B1, B2, C1, C2, D1, D2]

In my opinion the Tukey variant is the best choice if average=False or if T  is smaller than the maximum wavelet scale

@OverLordGoldDragon your comments are welcome!

issue.title: Input length requirement

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body:
Is it possible to modify the implementation of the scattering transform to avoid the need for a fixed-length input?

It could be very interesting if it can be done, especially in real-time audio analysis systems where the input length can change. For instance, a speech analysis tool.
